===Karnataka=== Karnataka is the top solar state in India exceeding 5,000 MW installed capacity by the end of financial year 2017-18.<ref name=top>{{cite web |url=https://mercomindia.com/top-solar-states-charts/ |title= India's Top 10 Solar States in Charts |accessdate=20 May 2018|date= 2018-05-17 }}</ref> The installed capacity of [[Pavagada Solar Park]] is 600 MW and its ultimate 2,000 MW installed capacity is expected by the end of year 2020.
===Andhra Pradesh=== {{main article|Power sector of Andhra Pradesh}}
Installed photovoltaic capacity in [[Andhra Pradesh]] is more than 2049 MW as on 31 July 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/press-release/solar-energy-installed-capacity-touched-13652-mw/1119037 |title= Solar Energy Installed Capacity Touched 13652 MW |accessdate=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://taiyangnews.info/markets/indias-4-8-gw-h1-installations-top-2016-additions/ |title= Cumulative Solar Power Capacity Of India Now Close To 14 GW With 7 States Crossing 1 GW Level By End of June |accessdate=2017-08-13}}</ref> In 2014, the [[Independent Power Producer|IPPs]] agreed with [[Transmission Corporation of Andhra Pradesh|APTransCo]] to install 619 MW.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aptransco.gov.in/transco/docs/whatsnew1/list-of-successful-bidders.pdf |title= AP Solar Bidding – 2014 |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref> The following year, [[NTPC Limited|NTPC]] agreed with APTransCo to install the 250-MW [[NP Kunta Ultra Mega Solar Power Project]] near [[Kadiri]] in [[Anantapur district]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/power-generation-begins-at-kunta-ultra-mega-solar-project-116051001059_1.html |title=Power generation begins at Kunta ultra mega solar project |accessdate=2016-05-11|newspaper=Business Standard India |date=2016-05-10 |last1=India |first1=Press Trust of }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/ntpc-signs-ppa-for-phase-1-of-1-000-mw-ultra-solar-project-with-ap-discoms-115042400659_1.html |title=NTPC signs PPA for phase 1 of 1,000 mw ultra solar project with AP discoms |accessdate=2014-06-23}}</ref> In October 2017, 1000 MW was commissioned at [[Kurnool Ultra Mega Solar Park]] which has become the world's largest solar power plant.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nrdc.org/experts/anjali-jaiswal/worlds-largest-solar-park-kurnool-india |title=The World's Largest Solar Park - Kurnool, India |accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref>
===Rajasthan=== [[Rajasthan]] is one of Indias most solar-developed states, with its total photovoltaic capacity reaching 2289 MW by the end of June, 2018. Rajasthan is also home to the worlds largest [[Compact linear Fresnel reflector|Fresnel type]] 125 MW [[Concentrated solar power|CSP]] plant at the [[Dhirubhai Ambani Solar Park]].<ref name=pg/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.estelasolar.org/techologies-plants/the-4-types-of-csp-electricity-technologies/linear-fresnel-reflector/ |title=Reliance Power commissions world's largest Solar CSP project in Rajasthan |date=12 November 2014 |accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref> [[Jodhpur district]] leads the state with installed capacity of over 1,500 MW, followed by [[Jaisalmer district|Jaisalmer]] and [[Bikaner district|Bikaner]].
The [[Bhadla Solar Park]], with a total ultimate capacity of 2,255 MW, is being developed in four phases of which 260 MW capacity was commissioned by [[NTPC Limited]]. Total installed capacity at the end of June, 2018 is 745 MW and the remaining capacity is expected to be commissioned by March, 2019. In September 2018 Acme Solar announced that it had commissioned India's cheapest solar power, 200 [[megawatt|MW]] at Bhadla <ref>{{cite news|title=Acme Solar Commissions India’s Cheapest Solar Power Plant|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2018/09/24/acme-solar-commissions-indias-cheapest-solar-power-plant/|accessdate=29 September 2018}}</ref>.
The only [[Solar power tower|tower type]] solar thermal power plant (2.5 MW) in India is located in Bikaner district.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nrel.gov/csp/solarpaces/project_detail.cfm/projectID=262|title=ACME solar tower plant |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref>
===Tamil Nadu=== [[Tamil Nadu]] has the 5th highest installed solar-power capacity in India on May 2018. The total installed capacity in Tamil Nadu is 1,8 GW.<ref name=top/> On 1 July 2017, Solar power tariff in Tamil Nadu has hit an all-time low of Rs 3.47 per unit when bidding for 1500 MW capacity was held.<ref>{{cite web |title= Solar power tariff plunges to record low in Tamil Nadu |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/solar-power-tariff-plunges-to-record-low-in-tamil-nadu/articleshow/59397492.cms|accessdate=1 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= NLC biggest winner in 1,500 Megawatt Tamil Nadu solar auction |url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/nlc-biggest-winner-in-1500-megawatt-tamil-nadu-solar-auction/59417298|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref>
The 648-MW [[Kamuthi Solar Power Project]] is the biggest operating project in the state. On 1 January 2018, [[NLC India Limited]] (NCIL) commissioned a new 130 MW solar power project in [[Neyveli]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/130-mw-solar-power-plant-commissioned-at-nevyeli/article22348029.ece | work=The Hindu| title=130-MW solar power plant commissioned at Neyveli | location= Cuddalore | date=2018-01-02}}</ref>
===Gujarat=== {{see also|Gujarat Solar Park}}
[[Gujarat]] is one of India's most solar-developed states, with its total photovoltaic capacity reaching 1,262 MW by the end of July 2017. Gujarat has been a leader in solar-power generation in India due to its high solar-power potential, availability of vacant land, connectivity, transmission and distribution infrastructure and utilities. According to a report by the [[Low Emission Development Strategies Global Partnership (LEDS GP)]] report, these attributes are complemented by political will and investment.{{full citation needed|date=May 2017}} The 2009 Solar Power of Gujarat policy framework, financing mechanism and incentives have contributed to a [[eco investing|green]] investment climate in the state and targets for grid-connected solar power.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ledsgp.org/resource/scaling-up-solar-energy-india-webinar/?loclang=en_gb |title=Pioneering and scaling up solar energy in India – webinar and related resources |work=The Low Emission Development Strategies Global Partnership}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://energyinfrapost.com/gujarat-government-buys-solar-power-rs-15-per-unit-38-firms/ |title=Gujarat government buys solar power at Rs 15 per unit from 38 firms |accessdate=2017-03-05|date=2017-03-04 }}</ref>
The state has commissioned Asia's largest solar park near the village of Charanka in [[Patan district]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/UserFiles/presentations-challenges_and_issues_in_solar_RPO_compliance_24072012/Charanka%20Solar%20Park%20(Gujarat)_GEDA_24.07.2012.pdf|title=Charanka Solar Park|website=[[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]]|format=pdf}}</ref> The park is generating 2 MW of its total planned capacity of 500 MW, and has been cited as an innovative and environmentally-friendly project by the [[Confederation of Indian Industry]].{{full citation needed|date=May 2017}}
To make [[Gandhinagar]] a solar-power city, the state government has begun a rooftop solar-power generation scheme. Under the scheme, Gujarat plans to generate 5 MW of solar power by putting solar panels on about 50 state-government buildings and 500 private buildings.
It also plans to generate solar power by putting solar panels along the Narmada canals. As part of this scheme, the state has commissioned the 1 MW [[Canal Solar Power Project]] on a branch of the [[Narmada Canal]] near the village of Chandrasan in [[Mehsana district]]. The pilot project is expected to stop {{convert|90000|l|usgal impgal}} of water per year from evaporating from the [[Narmada River]].
===Maharashtra=== The 125-MW [[Sakri solar plant]] is the largest solar-power plant in [[Maharashtra]]. The [[Sai Baba of Shirdi|Shri Saibaba Sansthan Trust]] has the world's largest solar steam system. It was constructed at the [[Shirdi]] shrine at an estimated cost of {{INRConvert|1.33|c}}, {{INRConvert|58.4|l}} which was paid as a subsidy by the renewable-energy ministry. The system is used to cook 50,000 meals per day for pilgrims visiting the shrine, resulting in annual savings of 100,000  kg of [[Fuel gas|cooking gas]], and was designed to generate steam for cooking even in the absence of electricity to run the circulating pump. The project to install and commission the system was completed in seven months, and the system has a design life of 25 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/shirdi-gets-largest-solar-cooking-system/495887/ |title= Shirdi Gets Largest Solar Cooking System}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/16952/shirdis-solar-cooker-finds-place.html |title=Shirdis solar cooker finds place|date=2009-07-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/business/shirdi-gets-worlds-largest-solar-steam-system_100225217.html |title=Shirdi Gets worlds largest solar steam system}}</ref> The [[Osmanabad]] region in Maharashtra has abundant sunlight, and is ranked the third-best region in India in solar insolation. A 10 MW solar power plant in Osmanabad was commissioned in 2013. The total power capacity of Maharashtra is about 500 MW.
===Madhya Pradesh=== [[Madhya Pradesh]] is one of India's most solar-developed states, with its total photovoltaic capacity reaching 1,117 MW by the end of July 2017. The [[Welspun Solar MP project]], the largest solar-power plant in the state, was built at a cost of {{INRConvert|1100|c}} on {{convert|305|ha|km2|abbr=on}} of land and will supply power at {{INRConvert|8.05}} per kWh. A 130 MW solar power plant project at Bhagwanpura, a village in [[Neemuch district]], was launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. It is the largest solar producer, and [[Welspun Energy]] is one of the top three companies in India's renewable-energy sector.<ref>{{cite web |title=Solar Projects|url=http://www.welspunrenewables.com/business.html |website=Welspun Renewables |publisher=Welspun Renewables}}, http://www.welspunenergy.com</ref> A planned 750 MW solar-power plant in [[Rewa district]] is also planned and expected to be completed in 2018. This is developing by [[Rewa Ultra Mega Solar]] Limited.<ref>[[Rewa Ultra Mega Solar]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=December 2017}}
=== Kerala=== India's largest floating solar power plant was set upon the [[Banasura Sagar Dam|Banasura Sagar reservoir]] in [[Wayanad district|Wayanad,]] [[Kerala]]. The 500 kW (kilowatt peak) solar plant of the Kerala state electricity board (KSEB) floats on 1.25 acres of the water surface of the reservoir. The solar plant has 1,938 solar panels which have been installed on 18 Ferro cement floaters with hollow insides.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/indias-largest-floating-solar-power-plant-opens-in-kerala/watt-a-sight/slideshow/61930256.cms |title=India's largest floating solar power plant opens in Kerala |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
==Electricity generation== Grid-connected solar electricity generation has reached nearly 2% of total utility electricity generation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cea.nic.in/reports/monthly/generation/2018/March/tentative/opm_01.pdf |title= Overview of power generation, March 2018, CEA|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> Solar generation meets the daytime peak load in non-monsoon months when electricity spot prices exceed the daily average price.<ref name=iex>{{cite web |url=http://www.iexindia.com/marketdata/areaprice.aspx |title=IEX Area prices |accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref>

=={{anchor|Photovoltaic solar growth forecasts}}Solar photovoltaic growth forecasts== In August 2016, the [[Growth of photovoltaics|forecast for solar photovoltaic]] installations was about 4.8 GW for the calendar year. About 2.8 GW was installed in the first eight months of 2016, more than all 2015 solar installations. India's solar projects stood at about 21 GW, with about 14 GW under construction and about 7 GW to be auctioned.<ref>http://mercomcapital.com/solar-installations-in-india-to-reach-4.8-gw-in-2016-with-a-21-gw-development-pipeline</ref> The country's solar capacity reached 19.7 GW by the end of 2017, making it the third-largest global solar market.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mercomindia.com/states-accounted-75-percent-indias-installations-2017/ |title=Four States Accounted for 75 Percent of India's Utility-Scale Solar Installations in 2017 |accessdate=14 March 2018|date=2018-03-14 }}</ref>
In mid-2018 the Indian power minister RK Singh flagged a tender for a 100GW solar plant at an event in Delhi, while discussing a 10GW tender due to be issued in July that year (at the time, a world record). He also increased the government target for installed renewable energy by 2022 to 227GW.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Safi |first1=Michael |title=India's huge solar ambitions could push coal further into shade |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/30/indias-huge-solar-ambitions-could-push-coal-further-into-shade |accessdate=30 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |agency=Guardian News and Media Limited}}</ref>
==Solar thermal power== [[File:PS10 solar power tower.jpg|thumb|Solar thermal power plant with a field of [[heliostat]]s and a central [[solar power tower]].]] The installed capacity of commercial [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal power]] plants (non storage type) in India is 227.5 MW with 50 MW in Andhra Pradesh and 177.5 MW in Rajasthan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energystorageexchange.org/projects/669 |title=DOE Energy storage database |accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1364032116300570-gr8.jpg |title=Direct Normal Irradiance in India |accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref> Solar thermal plants with thermal storage are emerging as cheaper (US 6.1 ¢/kWh or Rs 3.97/KWh) and clean [[load following power plant]]s to supply electricity round the clock,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/solarreserve-awarded-au78mwh-concentrated-solar-power-contract/|title=Solar Reserve awarded AU$78/MWh Concentrated Solar Power contract |accessdate= 23 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://helioscsp.com/15-gw-concentrated-solar-power-projects-to-compete-for-china-2nd-batch-pilot-projects/|title=15 GW Concentrated Solar Power projects to compete for China 2nd batch pilot projects |accessdate= 9 January 2018}}</ref> working as [[dispatchable generation]].<ref name=sther>{{cite web |url=http://reneweconomy.com.au/aurora-what-you-should-know-about-port-augustas-solar-power-tower-86715/|title=Aurora: What you should know about Port Augusta's solar power-tower |accessdate= 22 August 2017|date=2017-08-21 }}</ref> Proper mix of solar thermal (thermal storage type) and [[solar PV]] can fully match the load fluctuations without the need of costly battery storage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://solarthermalmagazine.com/2017/07/19/solarreserve-receives-environmental-approval-390-megawatt-solar-thermal-facility-storage-chile/|title=SolarReserve receives environmental approval 390 MW solar thermal facility storage in Chile |accessdate= 29 August 2017|date=2017-07-19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/03/13/solarreserve-bids-24-hour-solar-6-3-cents-chile/|title=SolarReserve Bids 24-Hour Solar At 6.3 Cents In Chile |accessdate= 29 August 2017|date=2017-03-13 }}</ref>
The existing solar thermal power plants (non-storage type) in India, which are generating costly intermittent power on daily basis, can be converted into storage type solar thermal plants to generate 3 to 4 times more baseload power at cheaper cost and not depend on government subsidies.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/is-csp-viable-without-storage#gs.9UN2YLg|title=Concentrating Solar Power Isn't Viable Without Storage, Say Experts |accessdate= 29 August 2017|date=November 2016 }}</ref>
==Hybrid solar plants== Solar power, generated mainly during the daytime in the non-monsoon period, complements wind which generate power during the monsoon months in India.{{cn|date=December 2018}} Solar panels can be located in the space between the towers of [[Wind power in India|wind-power plants]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/siemens-gamesa-bags-wind-solar-hydrid-energy-project-in-karnataka/60841883|title=Siemens Gamesa bags Wind-Solar hybrid energy project in Karnataka |accessdate= 28 September 2017}}</ref> It also complements hydroelectricity, generated primarily during India's monsoon months. Solar-power plants can be installed near existing hydropower and [[pumped-storage hydroelectricity]], utilizing the existing power transmission infrastructure and storing the surplus secondary power generated by the solar PV plants.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/shapoorji-pallonji-bags-countrys-first-large-scale-floating-solar-project/66837326|title=Shapoorji Pallonji bags country's first large-scale floating solar project |accessdate= 28 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.powermag.com/integrated-solar-hydro-project-takes-float/|title=Integrated Solar-Hydro Project Takes Float |accessdate= 1 September 2017|date=September 2017 }}</ref>
During the daytime, the additional auxiliary power consumption of a solar thermal storage power plant is nearly 10% of its rated capacity for the process of extracting solar energy in the form of thermal energy.<ref name=sther/> This auxiliary power requirement can be made available from cheaper solar PV plant by envisaging hybrid solar plant with a mix of solar thermal and solar PV plants at a site. Also to optimise the cost of power, generation can be from the cheaper solar PV plant (33% generation) during the daylight whereas the rest of the time in a day is from the solar thermal storage plant (67% generation from [[Solar power tower]] and [[parabolic trough]] types) for meeting 24 hours baseload power.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2015/08/25/cheap-baseload-solar-copiapo-gets-ok-chile-exclusive-info/|title=Cheap Baseload Solar At Copiapó Gets OK In Chile |accessdate= 1 September 2017|date=2015-08-25 }}</ref> When solar thermal storage plant is forced to idle due to lack of sunlight locally during cloudy days in monsoon season, it is also possible to consume (similar to a lesser efficient, huge capacity and low cost battery storage system) the cheap excess grid power when the grid frequency is above 50 [[Hertz|hz]] for heating the hot molten salt to higher temperature for converting stored thermal energy in to electricity during the peak demand hours when the electricity sale price is profitable.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2017/apr/06/salt-silicon-or-graphite-energy-storage-goes-beyond-lithium-ion-batteries|title=Salt, silicon or graphite: energy storage goes beyond lithium ion batteries |accessdate= 1 September 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |date=2017-04-05 |last1=Lewis |first1=Dyani }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/print/volume-18/issue-110/features/thermal-renewable-energy/commercializing-standalone-thermal-energy-storage.html|title=Commercializing Standalone Thermal Energy Storage |accessdate= 1 September 2017}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Solar heating}}Solar heating== [[File:Solar Array.jpg|thumb|Array of parabolic troughs.]] {{See also|Solar thermal energy}} Generating hot water or air or steam using concentrated solar reflectors, is increasing rapidly. Presently concentrated solar thermal installation base for heating applications is about 20 MW<sub>th</sub> in India and expected to grow rapidly.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/specials/clean-tech/solar-energy-green-energy-solar-water-heating/article9835418.ece |title=The sleeping giant is waking up |date=29 August 2017 |accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.financialexpress.com/india-news/solar-thermal-industry-seeks-govt-attention/1205269/ |title=Solar thermal industry seeks govt attention |accessdate=14 June 2018|date=2018-06-13 }}</ref> [[Cogeneration]] of steam and power round the clock is also feasible with [[concentrated solar power|solar thermal]] CHP plants with storage capacity.
[[Bengaluru]] has the largest deployment of roof-top solar water heaters in India, generating an energy equivalent of 200 MW.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bangalore/report_live-life-off-the-grid-or-tap-the-sunshine-in-your-backyard_1317492 |title=Solar Water Heater |publisher=Dnaindia.com |date=2009-11-28 |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref> It is India's first city to provide a rebate of {{INRconvert|50}} on monthly electricity bills for residents using roof-top thermal systems,<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://hindu.com/2009/11/26/stories/2009112655090600.htm |title=Solar Water Heater Rebate |newspaper=The Hindu |date=2009-11-26 |accessdate=2012-04-25}}</ref> which are now mandatory in all new structures. [[Pune]] has also made solar water heaters mandatory in new buildings.<ref>{{cite news |author=Dipannita Das |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/More-homes-opt-for-solar-energy/articleshow/5280270.cms |title=More homes opt for solar energy |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2009-11-29 |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref> [[Photovoltaic thermal hybrid solar collector|Photovoltaic thermal]] (PVT) panels produce simultaneously the required warm water/air along with electricity under sunlight.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/long-way-to-go-for-india-to-fulfil-renewable-energy-targets-expert/66372085 |title=PVT panels |accessdate=26 October 2018}}</ref>
==Rural electrification== The lack of an electricity infrastructure is a hurdle to rural India's development. India's power grid is under-developed, with large groups of people still living off the grid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.firstpost.com/living/dc-solar-products-are-lighting-up-rural-india-whats-driving-the-increased-demand-3386812.html |title=DC solar products are lighting up rural India: What's driving the increased demand? |accessdate=2017-04-15}}</ref> In 2004, about 80,000 of the nation's villages still did not have electricity; of them, 18,000 could not be electrified by extending the conventional grid. A target of electrifying 5,000 such villages was set for the [[Five-Year Plans of India#Tenth Plan (2002–2007)|2002–2007 Five-Year Plan]]. By 2004 more than 2,700 villages and hamlets were electrified, primarily with solar photovoltaic systems.<ref name="SPSEPRIE" /> The development of inexpensive solar technology is considered a potential alternative, providing an electricity infrastructure consisting of a network of local-grid clusters with distributed electricity generation.<ref name="ecoworld" >{{cite web |url=http://www.ecoworld.com/products/electronics/indias-solar-power.html |title=India's Solar Power: Greening India's Future Energy Demand |publisher=Ecoworld.com |date=2007-05-15 |accessdate=2012-02-28 |first=Avilash |last=Roul}}</ref> It could bypass (or relieve) expensive, long-distance, centralized power-delivery systems, bringing inexpensive electricity to large groups of people. In Rajasthan during FY2016-17, 91 villages have been electrified with a solar standalone system and over 6,200 households have received a 100W solar home-lighting system.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
India has sold or distributed about 1.2 million solar home-lighting systems and 3.2 million solar lanterns, and has been ranked the top Asian market for solar off-grid products.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/chinas-cheap-solar-panels-cause-dark-spots-in-indian-market/articleshow/45738182.cms |title=China's cheap solar panels cause dark spots in Indian market |accessdate=2015-01-03|newspaper=The Economic Times |date=2015-01-03 |last1=Upadhyay |first1=Anindya }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/fullnews-84794.html |title=Solar power in 3,000 Odisha villages by 2014 |publisher=Newkerala.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oredaorissa.com/admin.htm |title=The Orissa Renewable Energy Development Agency (OREDA) was constituted as a State Nodal agency in the 1984 |publisher=Oredaorissa.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://energybusiness.in/orissa-approves-nine-solar-power-projects/ |title=The Energy Business – India Energy News, Nuclear Energy News, Renewable Energy News, Oil & Gas Sector News, Power Sector News " Orissa approves nine solar power projects |publisher=Energybusiness.in |date= |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref>
==={{anchor|Solar lamps and lighting}}Lamps and lighting=== By 2012, a total of 4,600,000 solar lanterns and 861,654 solar-powered home lights were installed. Typically replacing kerosene lamps, they can be purchased for the cost of a few months' worth of kerosene with a small loan. The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy is offering a 30- to 40-percent subsidy of the cost of lanterns, home lights and small systems (up to 210 [[Nominal power (photovoltaic)#Watt-peak|W<sub>p</sub>]]).<ref>[http://pib.nic.in/newsite/pmreleases.aspx?mincode=28 Government Provides 30% subsidy for Solar Lanterns and Home Lights]</ref> Twenty million solar lamps are expected by 2022.<ref name=actionplan>[http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=83632 Action Plan to Increase Renewable Energy]</ref>
===Agricultural support=== Solar photovoltaic water-pumping systems are used for irrigation and drinking water.<ref name= modpri>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/10/23/indian-module-makers-beat-chinese-prices-300-megawatt-tender/ |title=Indian Module Makers Beat Chinese Prices In 300 Megawatt Tender |accessdate=23 October 2017|date=2017-10-23 }}</ref> Most pumps are fitted with a {{convert|200|–|3000|W|hp|abbr=on}} motor powered with a 1,800 W<sub>p</sub> PV array which can deliver about {{convert|140,000|l|USgal}} of water per day from a total [[hydraulic head]] of {{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}}. By 30 September 2006 a total of 7,068 solar photovoltaic water pumping systems were installed,<ref name="ecoworld"/> and 7,771 were installed by March 2012.<ref name="Press Information Bureau Release">[http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=86742 Government Provides 30 per cent subsidy for Solar Lanterns and Home Lights]</ref> During hot sunny daytime when the water needs are more for watering the fields, solar pumps performance can be improved by maintaining pumped water flowing/sliding over the solar panels to keep them cooler and clean.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.energysage.com/solar-panel-temperature-overheating/ |title=How hot do solar panels get? Effect of temperature on solar performance |accessdate=1 August 2018|date=2017-06-15 }}</ref> Solar driers are used to dry harvests for storage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a723775318~db=all |title=Solar chilli drier |publisher=Informaworld.com |date=2005-09-01 |accessdate=2010-11-27}}</ref> Low cost solar powered bicycles are also available to ply between fields and village for agricultural activity, etc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/education/story/engineering-student-from-pune-solar-powered-bicycle/1/1118099.html |title=Meet this engineering student from Pune who has built a solar powered bicycle |accessdate=2017-12-27}}</ref>
===Rainwater harvesting=== In addition to solar energy, rainwater is a major [[renewable resource]] of any area. In India, large areas are being covered by solar PV panels every year. Solar panels can also be used for harvesting most of the rainwater falling on them and drinking-quality water, free from bacteria and suspended matter, can be generated by simple [[Water purification|filtration and disinfection]] processes, as rainwater is very low in [[salinity]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rain fed solar-powered water purification systems. |url=http://www.windpowerengineering.com/environmental/wind-solar-powered-offgridbox-useful-hurricane-passes/|accessdate=21 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://inhabitat.com/new-rooftop-solar-hydropanels-harvest-drinking-water-and-energy-at-the-same-time/ |title=New rooftop solar hydro panels harvest drinking water and energy at the same time |accessdate=2017-11-30}}</ref> Good quality water resources, closer to populated areas, are becoming a scarcity and increasingly costly for consumers. Exploitation of rainwater for value-added products like bottled drinking water makes solar PV power plants profitable even in high rainfall and cloudy areas by the increased income from drinking water generation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Inverted Umbrella Brings Clean Water & Clean Power To India |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/12/04/inverted-umbrella-brings-clean-water-clean-power-india/|accessdate=5 December 2017|date=2017-12-04}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Solar refrigeration and air conditioning}}Refrigeration and air conditioning== [[Image:4MW single axis horizontal tracker in Vellakoil, Tamil Nadu, India.jpg|thumb|upright=2|alt=Many solar panels arranged horizontally at ground level|4 MW horizontal single-axis tracker in [[Vellakoil]], Tamil Nadu]]
[[Thin-film solar cell]] panels offer better performance than crystalline silica solar panels in tropical hot and dusty places like India; there is less deterioration in conversion efficiency with increased ambient temperature, and no partial shading effect. These factors enhance the performance and reliability (fire safety) of thin-film panels.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-educationplus/now-solar-energy-can-power-air-conditioner-refrigerator/article8378355.ece |title=Now, solar energy can power air conditioner, refrigerator |accessdate=2016-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Thin Film Solar PV vs Silicon Wafer – Which is Better? |url=http://www.solarblogger.net/2016/10/thin-film-solar-pv-vs-silicon-wafer.html |accessdate=2017-03-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Panasonic HIT solar module achieves world's best output temperature coefficient |url=http://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/2017/06/panasonic-hit-solar-module-achieves-worlds-best-output-temperature-coefficient/ |accessdate=2017-06-22|date=2017-06-22 }}</ref> Maximum solar-electricity generation during the hot hours of the day can be used for meeting residential air-conditioning requirements regardless of other load requirements, such as refrigeration, lighting, cooking and water pumping. Power generation of photovoltaic modules can be increased by 17 to 20 percent by equipping them with a [[Solar tracker|tracking system]].<ref>{{cite web |title= The use of solar trackers is picking up fast in India |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/specials/clean-tech/moving-with-the-sun/article8812097.ece |accessdate=2016-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Bifacial Plus Tracking Boosts Solar Energy Yield by 27 Percent |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/bifacial-plus-tracking-boosts-solar-energy-yield-by-27-percent#gs.zVmaRi8 |accessdate=19 April 2018|date=2018-04-18 }}</ref>
Residential electricity consumers who are paying higher slab rates more than {{INRConvert|5}} per unit, can form in to local groups to install collectively roof top off-grid solar power units (without much battery storage) and replace the costly power used from the grid with the solar power as and when produced.<ref>{{cite web |title= Solar power essential data |url=https://www.itsmysun.com/solar-essentials/ |accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref> Hence power drawl from the grid which is an assured power supply without much power cuts nowadays, serves as cheaper back up source when grid power consumption is limited to lower slab rate by using solar power during the day time. The maximum power generation of solar panels during the sunny daytime is complementary with the enhanced residential electricity consumption during the hot/summer days due to higher use of cooling appliances such as fans, refrigerators, air conditioners, desert coolers, etc. It would discourage the Discoms to extract higher electricity charges selectively from its consumers.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Rs 3 per KWh – lowest tariff for third-party rooftop solar power installations |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/chandigarh-himachal-uttarakhand-to-get-cheapest-power-gujarat-to-costliest/articleshow/54926741.cms |accessdate=2016-10-19|newspaper=The Economic Times |date=2016-10-19 |last1=Sengupta |first1=Debjoy }}</ref> There is no need of any permission from Discoms similar to [[Standby generator|DG power sets]] installation. Cheaper discarded batteries of [[Battery electric vehicle|electric vehicle]] can also be used economically to store the excess solar power generated in the daylight.<ref>{{cite web |title=Giving electric vehicle batteries a second life in solar projects |url=http://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/2017/02/giving-electric-vehicle-batteries-second-life-solar-projects/ |accessdate=2017-02-28|date=2017-02-20 }}</ref>
=={{anchor|Power grid stabilisation}}Grid stabilisation== {{See also|Solar inverter|Tesla Powerwall}} Solar-power plants equipped with [[Rechargeable battery|battery]]-storage systems where [[net energy metering]] is used can feed stored electricity into the power grid when its frequency is below the rated parameter (50 Hz) and draw excess power from the grid when its frequency is above the rated parameter.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/aes-energy-storage-and-panasonic-target-india-for-grid-batteries |title=AES Energy Storage and Panasonic Target India for Grid Batteries |accessdate=2016-04-16}}</ref> Excursions above and below the rated grid frequency occur about 100 times daily.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nldc.in/2013-03-12-10-34-42/frequency-profile |title= Frequency Profile, NLDC, GoI |accessdate= 2015-08-06 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cleantechnica.com/2016/02/25/india-plans-750-mw-solar-power-park-100-mw-storage-capacity/ |title=India Plans 750 MW Solar Power Park With 100 MW Storage Capacity |accessdate=2016-03-01|date=2016-02-25 }}</ref> The solar-plant owner would receive nearly double the price for electricity sent into the grid compared to that consumed from the grid if a frequency-based tariff is offered to rooftop solar plants or plants dedicated to a distribution substation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://indiapowertrading.info/real-time-power-grid-frequency/ |title=Real Time DSM tariff |accessdate=2015-08-06}}</ref><ref name=dsm>{{cite web |url=http://cercind.gov.in/2014/regulation/noti132.pdf |title=Deviation Settlement Mechanism and related matters, CERC, GoI |accessdate=2015-08-06}}</ref> A power-purchase agreement (PPA) is not needed for solar plants with a [[Battery management system|battery storage system]] to serve [[Availability-based tariff|ancillary-service operations]] and transmit generated electricity for captive consumption using an open-access facility.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/rays-future-energy-executes-60-mw-of-capacity-under-open-access/62179165 |title=Rays Future Energy executes 60 MW of capacity under open access |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2017/06/28/audi-electric-car-battery-cost/ |title=Audi claims to be buying batteries at ~$114/kWh for its upcoming electric cars, says CTO |date=2017-06-30}}</ref> Battery storage is popular in India, with more than 10 million households using battery backup during [[load shedding]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.solarquarter.com/index.php/technology/504-global-solar-storage-market-a-review-of-2015 |title=Global Solar Storage Market: A Review Of 2015 |date=2016-04-06}}</ref> Battery storage systems are also used to improve the [[power factor]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/05/18/3778623/new-economics-solar-plus-battery-storage/ |title=Storing The Sun's Energy Just Got A Whole Lot Cheaper |accessdate=2016-05-23}}</ref> Solar PV or wind paired with four-hour battery storage systems is already cost competitive, without subsidy, as a source of dispatchable generation compared with new coal and new gas plants in India”.<ref>{{cite web|title=Solar and wind now the cheapest power source says Bloomberg NEF |url=https://www.powerengineeringint.com/articles/2018/11/solar-and-wind-now-the-cheapest-power-source-says-bloombergnef.html |accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref>
Battery storage is also used economically to reduce daily/monthly [[Peak shaving|peak power demand]] for minimising the monthly demand charges from the utility to the commercial and industrial establishments.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2017/06/30/egeb-2/ |title=Energy storage already cost-competitive in commercial sector |accessdate=2017-06-30|date=2017-06-30 }}</ref> Construction power tariffs are very high in India.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tangedco.gov.in/linkpdf/ONE_PAGE_STATEMENT.pdf |title=Construction power tariff |date=2017-10-06}}</ref> Construction power needs of long gestation mega projects can be economically met by installing solar PV plants for permanent service in the project premises with or without battery storage for minimising use of [[Standby generator]] sets or costly grid power.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sol-solutions.com/solar-generator-and-light-tower-uses/construction-site-power-lighting.html |title=Construction Site Power and Lighting |date=2017-10-06}}</ref>
==Challenges and opportunities== {{See also|Energy policy of India#Solar energy}} The land is scarce in India, and per-capita land availability is low{{Citation needed|reason=No allowance made for unproductive land, no actual land figures quoted from any source. See refs 98/99 in Energy_policy_of_India|date=June 2018}}. Dedication of land for the installation of solar arrays must compete with other needs. The amount of land required for utility-scale solar power plants is about {{convert|1|km2|acre|abbr=on}} for every 40–60 MW generated. One alternative is to use the water-surface area [[Canal Solar Power Project|on canals]], lakes, reservoirs, farm ponds and the sea for large solar-power plants.<ref>{{cite web |title=Floating solar energy transforming India into a greener nation|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/energy-speak/floating-solar-energy-transforming-india-into-a-greener-nation/3312|accessdate=31 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Solar floats in the sunshine state|url=http://www.solarpowerworldonline.com/2017/02/solar-floats-sunshine-state/|accessdate=1 March 2017|date=2017-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Green Power Island: A blue battery for green energy|url=http://www.gottliebpaludan.com/en/project/green-power-island|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> These water bodies can also provide water to clean the solar panels.<ref>{{cite web |title=NTPC installs Robotic Dry Cleaning System for Solar PV Plant at NTPC Dadri|url=https://energyinfrapost.com/ntpc-installs-robotic-dry-cleaning-system-solar-pv-plant-ntpc-dadri/|accessdate=25 February 2017|date=2017-02-23}}</ref> Highways and railways may also avoid the cost of land nearer to load centres, minimising transmission-line costs by having solar plants about 10 meters above the roads or rail tracks.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Some of the UK's trains could be running on solar power by 2020|journal=Wired UK|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/in-the-future-trains-will-be-solar-powered|accessdate=6 December 2017|date=2017-12-06}}</ref> Solar power generated by road areas may also be used for in-motion charging of [[electric vehicle]]s, reducing fuel costs.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://ias.ieee.org/images/files/Webinars/IAS-webinar---Zeljko-Pantic---June-2016.pdf|title=Review of Recent Advances in Dynamic and Omnidirectional Wireless Power Transfer |accessdate=7 July 2016}}</ref> Highways would avoid damage from rain and summer heat, increasing comfort for commuters.<ref>{{cite web |title=Indian Scientists Propose Solar Roofs For Roads|url=http://cleantechnica.com/2013/04/02/indian-scientists-propose-solar-roofs-for-roads/|accessdate=17 November 2015|date=2013-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=World's First Solar Road Exceeds Expectations|url=http://www.enn.com/business/article/49158|accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Greenhouse solar can plug the massive need for land to promote renewable energy |url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/greenhouse-solar-can-plug-the-massive-need-for-land-to-promote-renewable-energy/51152523|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref>
The architecture best suited to most of India would be a set of rooftop power-generation systems connected via a local grid.<ref>{{cite web |title=In Brooklyn, you can now sell solar power to your neighbors |url=http://www.salon.com/2017/05/27/in-brooklyn-you-can-now-sell-solar-power-to-your-neighbors_partner/|accessdate=27 May 2017}}</ref> Such an infrastructure, which does not have the economy of scale of mass, utility-scale solar-panel deployment, needs a lower deployment price to attract individuals and family-sized households. Photovoltaics are projected to continue their cost reductions, becoming able to compete with fossil fuels.<ref>{{Cite news|title=landed solar module prices drop 15% in three months leads to glut |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/landed-solar-module-prices-drop-15-in-three-months-leads-to-glut-bridge-to-india/articleshow/54407920.cms|accessdate=19 September 2016|newspaper=The Economic Times|date=2016-09-19|last1=Sengupta|first1=Debjoy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Determination of Benchmark Capital Cost Norm for Solar PV power projects applicable during FY 2015-16, CERC |url=http://www.ireeed.gov.in/policyfiles/448-CERC%20solar%20tariff.pdf|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref>

Fifty-one solar radiation resource assessment stations have been installed across India by the [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] (MNRE) to create a database of solar-energy potential. Data is collected and reported to the Centre for Wind Energy Technology (C-WET) to create a solar atlas. In June 2015, India began a {{INRConvert|40|c}} project to measure solar radiation with a [[Angular resolution|spatial resolution]] of {{convert|3|x|3|km}}. This solar-radiation measuring network will provide the basis for the Indian solar-radiation atlas. According to National Institute of Wind Energy officials, the Solar Radiation Resource Assessment wing (121 ground stations) would measure solar radiation's three parameters—Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI), Direct Normal Irradiance (DNI) and Diffuse Horizontal Irradiance (DHI)—to accurately measure a region's solar radiation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/chennai/Solar-Radiation-Measuring-Network-Atlas-Out-in-the-Open/2015/06/04/article2848559.ece |title=Solar radiation measuring network in India|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://niwe.res.in/indian_solar_atlas.php|title=Solar radiation data collection agency in India|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
The Indian government is promoting solar energy. It announced an allocation of {{INRConvert|1000|c}} for the [[Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission]] and a clean-energy fund for the 2010-11 fiscal year, an increase of {{INRConvert|380|c}} from the previous budget. The budget encouraged private solar companies by reducing the import duty on solar panels by five percent. This is expected to reduce the cost of a rooftop solar-panel installation by 15 to 20 percent.
===Solar PV tariff=== [[File:Price history of silicon PV cells since 1977.svg|thumb|alt=Bar graph|Price of silicon [[solar cell]]s since 1977. The great thing about solar power is that it is a technology and not a fuel. It is unlimited and the more it is deployed the cheaper it would be. While the more limited fossil fuels are used, the more expensive they become.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-20/solar-prices-nosedive-after-china-pullback-floods-global-market |title=Solar Prices Nosedive After China Pullback Floods Global Market |accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/Solar-Costs-Are-Hitting-Jaw-Dropping-Lows-In-Every-Region-of-the-World |title=Solar Costs Are Hitting Jaw-Dropping Lows in Every Region of the World |accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>]]
The average bid in [[reverse auction]]s in April 2017 is {{INRConvert|3.15}} per kWh, compared with {{INRConvert|12.16}} per kWh in 2010, which is around 73% drop over the time window.<ref>{{cite web |title=Solar power tariff hits a new low at Rs 3.15 levelised rate |url=http://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/solar-power-tariff-hits-a-new-low-at-rs-3-15-levelised-rate/58139132 |accessdate=2017-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Solar tariffs in India have fallen by 73 percent since 2010 |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-tariffs-in-india-have-fallen-by-73-percent-since-2010/articleshow/57809228.cms |accessdate=2017-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Solar tariffs in India have fallen by 73% since 2010 |url=http://www.livemint.com/Industry/xkdwxNscR9K6omngOwOaAN/Solar-tariffs-in-India-have-fallen-by-73-since-2010-Mercom.html |accessdate=2017-03-24|date=2017-03-24 }}</ref> The current prices of solar PV electricity is around 18% lower than the average price for electricity generated by coal-fired plants.<ref name="bbcParisClimateDeal" /> Competitive reverse auctions, falling panel and component prices, the introduction of solar parks, lower borrowing costs and large power companies have contributed to the fall in prices. The cost of solar PV power in India, China, Brazil and 55 other emerging markets fell to about one-third of its 2010 price, making solar the cheapest form of renewable energy and cheaper than power generated from fossil fuels such as coal and gas.<ref>{{cite web |title=This Just Became the World's Cheapest Form of Electricity Out of Nowhere |url=http://fortune.com/2016/12/15/solar-electricity-energy-generation-cost-cheap/ |website=Fortune |accessdate=2017-02-05}}</ref>
The [[Cost of electricity by source|levelized cost]] of solar PV electricity fell below 1.77¢ US per kWh in November 2017, cheaper than fuel cost of any pit head coal-based power plants in India.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/mexico-auction-bids-lowest-solar-wind-price-on-the-planet#gs.Tm12cfs |title=Mexico's Energy Auction Just Logged the Lowest Solar Power Price on the Planet |accessdate=2017-11-23|date=2017-11-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Birth of a New Era in Solar PV — Record Low Cost On Saudi Solar Project Bid |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/10/07/the-birth-of-a-new-era-in-solar-pv-record-low-cost-on-saudi-solar-project-bid/ |accessdate= 7 October 2017|date=2017-10-07 }}</ref> The intermittent / non-dispatchable solar PV at the prevailing low tariffs clubbed with [[Thermal energy storage#Pumped-heat electricity storage|Pumped-heat electricity storage]] can offer cheapest [[Dispatchable generation|dispatchable power]] round the clock on demand.
The Indian government has reduced the solar PV power purchase price from the maximum allowed {{INRConvert|4.43|2}} per KWh to {{INRConvert|4.00|2}} per KWh, reflecting the steep fall in cost of solar power-generation equipment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/business/solar-power-tariff-dips-to-all-time-low-of-rs-4-per-unit-4363579/ |title=Solar power tariff dips to all-time low of Rs 4 per unit|accessdate=10 November 2016|date=2016-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://indianpowersector.com/2015/12/seci-lowers-the-solar-tariff-to-inr-4-43-per-unit-fixed-for-upcoming-biddings/ |title=SECI lowers the solar tariff to INR 4.43 per unit fixed for upcoming biddings |accessdate=2015-12-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/economy/cerc-capital-cost-move-suggests-solar-tariff-to-fall-further-in-fy17/183752/ |title=CERC capital cost move suggests solar tariff to fall further in FY17 |accessdate=2015-12-25}}</ref> The applicable tariff is offered after applying [[Public–private partnership|viability gap funding]] (VGF) or accelerated depreciation (AD) incentives.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/grid-solar/Scheme-2000MW-Grid-Connected-SPV-with-VGF-under-JNNSM.pdf |title=Grid Connected SPV with VGF under JNNSM |accessdate=2015-12-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-auction-companies-seeking-lowest-state-support-win/articleshow/52138023.cms |title=Solar auction companies seeking lowest state support to win |accessdate=2016-05-10|newspaper=The Economic Times |date=2016-05-06 |last1=Chandrasekaran |first1=Kaavya }}</ref>
Solar PV generation cost fell to {{INRConvert|2.97|2}} per kWh for the 750 MW [[Rewa Ultra Mega Solar]] power project, India's lowest electricity-generation cost.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-power-tariffs-fall-to-rs-2-97-per-unit/articleshow/57085143.cms |title=Solar tariffs fall to Rs. 2.97 per unit |accessdate=2017-02-11|newspaper=The Economic Times |date=2017-02-10 |last1=Singh |first1=Sarita }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.livemint.com/Industry/3xHqGD3VsLyixDdN0wpsZN/For-Rewa-project-were-not-interested-in-profits-Manu-Shri.html |title=For Rewa project, we're not interested in profits: Manu Srivastava |accessdate=2017-02-14|date=2017-02-13 }}</ref> [[Solar panel]] prices are lower than those of mirrors by unit area.<ref name= modpri/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/solar-tariffs-crash-to-below-rs-3-in-madhya-pradesh-auctions/article9533738.ece |title=Solar tariffs crash to below Rs. 3 in Madhya Pradesh auctions |accessdate=2017-02-10}}</ref>

Price|url=http://pv.energytrend.com/pricequotes.html |accessdate=18 June 2017}}</ref>
The lowest solar tariff in May 2018 is Rs 2.71/kWh (without incentives) which is less than the tariff of Badla solar park ({{INRConvert|2.44}} per kWh with VGF incentive) after the clarification that any additional taxes are pass through cost with hike in the tariff.<ref>{{cite web|title=L1 Tariff of ₹2.71/kWh Quoted in MSEDCL's 1 GW Solar Auction|url=https://mercomindia.com/l1-tariff-1gw-solar-auction-msedcl/ |accessdate=17 May 2018|date=2018-05-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Govt amends solar bidding norms, developers can now pass on duty hike|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/govt-amends-solar-bidding-norms-developers-can-now-pass-on-duty-hike/63606425 |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> In early July 2018 bids, the lowest solar PV tariff has touched {{INRConvert|2.44}} per kWh without VGF incentive.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Solar tariffs once again hit all-time low of Rs 2.44 a unit at SECI auction |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-tariffs-once-again-hit-all-time-low-of-rs-244-a-unit-at-seci-auction/articleshow/64834531.cms |accessdate=4 July 2018|newspaper=The Economic Times |date=2018-07-03 |last1=Chandrasekaran |first1=Kaavya }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Solar Tariffs in India Remain Steady at ₹2.44/kWh in SECI's 3 GW Auction |url=https://mercomindia.com/seci-3-gw-solar-ists-auction-results/|accessdate=14 July 2018|date=2018-07-13}}</ref> The tariff for roof top installations are also falling with the recent offer of {{INRConvert|3.64}} with 100% locally made components.<ref>{{cite web|title=CleanMax Quotes L1 Tariff of ₹3.64/kWh for NREDCAP's Rooftop Solar Tender|url=https://mercomindia.com/cleanmax-l1-bidder-nredcap-rooftop-solar-tender/ |accessdate=26 July 2018|date=2018-07-24 }}</ref>
==={{anchor|Government Incentives}}Incentives=== [[File:Grid parity map.svg|thumb|upright=2|alt=Colour-coded world map|[[Grid parity]] for solar PV systems around the world<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/3190409/sustainable-it/unsubsidized-wind-and-solar-now-the-cheapest-source-for-new-electric-power.html |title=Unsubsidized wind and solar now the cheapest source for new electric-power |accessdate=19 April 2017|date=2017-04-17 }}</ref><br/>{{legend2|#00CC66|border=1px solid #666|Reached grid-parity before 2014}}<br/>{{legend2|#66a6a6|border=1px solid #666|Reached grid-parity after 2014}}<br/>{{legend2|#a6a666|border=1px solid #666|Reached grid-parity after 2016}}<br/>{{legend2|#ff9955|border=1px solid #666|U.S. states poised to reach grid-parity soon}}]] At the end of July 2015, the chief incentives were: #Viability Gap Funding: Under the reverse bidding process, bidders who need least viability gap funding at the reference tariff (RS 4.93 per unit in 2016) is selected.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/cabinet-clears-viability-gap-funding-for-5-000-mw-solar-power-projects-116012000821_1.html|title=Cabinet clears viability gap funding for 5,000 Mw solar power projects|last=Jai|first=Shreya|date=2016-01-20|work=Business Standard India|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>. Funding was Rs 1 Crore/MW for open projects on average in 2016. #Accelerated depreciation: For profit-making enterprises installing rooftop solar systems, 40 percent of the total investment could be claimed as depreciation in the first year (decreasing taxes). #To protect the local solar panel manufacturers, 25% safe guard duty is imposed for two years period from August 2018 on the imports from China & Malaysia who are suspected of dumping solar panels in to India.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/renewable/india-imposes-safeguard-duty-on-solar-cells-imports-for-two-years/65206347 |title=India imposes safeguard duty on solar cells imports for two years|accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref> #Capital subsidies were applicable to rooftop solar-power plants up to a maximum of 500 kW. The 30-percent subsidy was reduced to 15 percent. #Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs): Tradeable certificates providing financial incentives for every unit of green power generated.<ref>[http://mnre.gov.in/pdf/MNRE_REC_Report.pdf Report On Development of Conceptual Framework For Renewable Energy Certificate Mechanism for India]</ref> #[[Net metering]] incentives depend on whether a net meter is installed and the utility's incentive policy. If so, financial incentives are available for the power generated.<ref>[http://www.solarmango.com/ask/2015/07/29/incentives-available-for-rooftop-solar-installations-in-india/ Government Incentives for Rooftop Solar Installation in India]</ref> #Assured Power Purchase Agreement (PPA): The power-distribution and -purchase companies owned by state and central governments guarantee the purchase of solar PV power when produced only during daylight. The PPAs offer fair market determined tariff for the solar power which is a secondary power or negative [[Load profile|load]] and an [[intermittent energy source]] on a daily basis. #Interstate transmission system (ISTS) charges and losses are not levied during the period of PPA for the projects commissioned before 31 March 2022.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mercomindia.com/no-ists-charges-wind-solar-projects-commissioned-2022/ |title=Ministry of Power Waives ISTS Charges for Wind and Solar Projects Commissioned up to 2022|accessdate=18 February 2018|date=2018-02-16}}</ref> #Additional incentives are offered to roof top solar power plants both from central and various state governments.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mercomindia.com/madhya-pradesh-solar-rooftop-tender-lowest-tariff/ |title=Madhya Pradesh's 35 MW Solar Rooftop Tender Sets Historic Lowest Tariff of ₹1.58/kWh|accessdate=29 August 2018|date=2018-08-29}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Bulk raw materials of solar panels}}Solar-panel manufacturing== The 2018 manufacturing capacity of [[solar cell]]s and [[solar module]]s in India was 1,590 MW and 5,620 MW, respectively.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/solar-manufacturing-industry-still-waiting-to-take-off-bridge-to-india/articleshow/52293909.cms |title=Solar manufacturing industry still waiting to take off |accessdate=2016-05-17}}</ref> Except for [[crystalline silicon]] [[Wafer (electronics)|wafers]] or [[cadmium telluride photovoltaics]] or [[Float-zone silicon]], nearly 80 percent of solar-panel weight is [[flat glass]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clca.columbia.edu/6_Burrows_Fthenakis_SolarMaterials.pdf |title=Glass Needs for a Growing Photovoltaics Industry |accessdate=2015-07-29}}</ref> One hundred to 150 tons of flat glass is used to manufacture a one-MW solar panel. Low-iron flat or [[float glass]] is manufactured from [[soda ash]] and iron-free [[silica]]. Soda-ash manufacturing from [[common salt]] is an energy-intensive process if it is not extracted from [[soda lake]]s or [[glasswort]] cultivation in [[alkali soil]]. To increase installation of photovoltaic solar-power plants, the production of flat glass and its raw materials must expand commensurately to eliminate supply constraints or future imports.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cstep.in/uploads/default/files/publications/stuff/CSTEP_Addressing_the_Challenges_of_RE_Manufacturing_in_India_Report_2015.pdf |title=Addressing the Challenges of RE Manufacturing in India |accessdate=2017-07-29}}</ref>
For utility scale solar projects, top solar module suppliers in 2016-17 were: Trina Solar, JA Solar, Canadian Solar, Risen, Hanwha and GCL Poly.<ref>{{cite web|title=India Solar Map - 2017|url=http://www.bridgetoindia.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/India-Solar-Map-September-2017.pdf|publisher=BRIDGE TO INDIA|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref> For rooftop solar projects, international companies with the largest market share in the Indian market were: Trina Solar, Canadian Solar, Renesola, REC Solar and Jinko Solar.<ref>{{cite web |title=Solar panels score board |url=http://www.solarscorecard.com/2014/score-guidelines.php |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> Similarly, top Indian suppliers were: Vikram Solar, Waaree, Adani, Emmvee and Jakson.<ref>{{cite web|title=Top solar panel suppliers in India - 2017|url=http://loopsolar.com/top-solar-panel-companies-in-India.html|publisher=Loop Solar|accessdate=20 September 2017}}</ref>
